text:
OK, the last section
of today's lab

is going to apply clustering and
Principal Components Analysis,

PCA methods to one of the
data sets in the ISLP package.

So this is a
microarray data set.

And it has the feature that it's
going to be more data than we
saw in our earlier examples.

We've only looked
at toy data sets.

And with four features
for the USA arrests.

And we generated data
for clusters as well.

OK, so this data is
quite a wide matrix.

There's 64 cases and
roughly 7,000 features.
So--

And the cases are
different types of cancer.

Yeah, these are
different tumors.

And we have some
biological measurement,

a microarray measurement
on each of the--

7,000 different
measurements on each tumor.

So in clustering
here, we're looking

to see whether, in terms of
these microarray measurements,

whether different
tumors are related.

If we knew what kind of cancer
they were-- which we do here,
we have labels for each of them.

We might expect that breast
cancer tumor behaves similarly

within themselves and
leukemia behaves similarly
within themselves.

And we're going to try and
see whether that happens.

So often when doing
clustering or PCA,

we might have some
label that's held out

that we don't use to fit
these unsupervised methods.

As at least a visual
validation, we often

will color points in a
principal component analysis

by the label to see whether
this PCA analysis reconstructs
somehow these labels.

If you look around
online, there's
actually a really nice--
what is it, is it November?
Is that the genetics article?

There's a really nice coloring
of a principal component

analysis of genetic
data in Europe

that reproduces
the map of Europe.

That's an example of
one of these things.

November, yeah, I
think is the author.
Yes.
OK, moving on.

So we have 64 rows
and 7,000 features.

Now if we run PCA, well,
in the USA arrest data,

we had four features and we
got four principal components.

So we might hope that we'd get
7,000 principal components.

But of course, that's not
going to be possible, right?

So PCA is only going to give us,
well, the minimum of, I think,

the number of
observations minus 1

and the number of
columns of the data.

So we're going to get
63 principal components.
At most.
Yes.
Yeah.

We won't have to keep
all of them, yes.

Yes, of course,
it could be less.
The mathematician speaks.
OK.

So here we have a
summary of the labels.

So we can see there there are,
I think, 13 different kinds
of cancer tumors.
And they're broken down.

Some of them have names that
are interpretable to many of us.

And these are very
specific ones.
OK.

So let's run a PCA on
the microarray data.
We're going to scale the data.

Though in this case, since
all of the measurements

are in the same unit, they're
all the same kind of assay.
We may not need to scale it.

But just, it's common
practice to scale it.

So we're going to
continue with that.
OK, so let's see.

We can find the principal
component scores
using the fit transform method.

And we're going to, again,
make a scatter plot.

And as I said before,
it's common practice

if you have a label to
label the plots in--

this is something like
the biplot we saw before.

Though I haven't indicated I
haven't added the vectors here
for the directions.

And in fact, that would
be pretty dense, right.

There would be 7,000
vectors or so here.

This is the first
and the second,

and this is the
first and the third.

And what we're
looking at here is

trying to get a sense of
whether there is clustering
in these principal components.

And there's these green
ones are in similar location
for the first two.

There's some evidence
of clustering.
Again, the color map is not--

it maybe not optimal,
because I can't actually

tell whether this blue is
different from that blue
just by looking at this.

So probably best to make a
better color map, if you can.

So there is an argument
to the scatter plot

that would allow us to
change the color map.

OK, so let's take a
look at the similar plot
we saw for the US ARS data.

We're going to plot the
percent variance explained

and the cumulative percent
variance explained.

So remember, for
the US ARS data,

I think the first principal
component had 60 odd percent
of the variance explained.
So here, 15%.

And that's actually still quite
a lot for 7,000 variables,
right?

If it was sort of
completely randomly spread,

it would be one
out of 7,000 or so.

So now inevitably,
if you're going

to use these principal
components for more than just

looking at plots like this,
you might use-- for instance,

you might use principal
components in regression,

like we saw in the end
of the lab in Chapter 6.

Though we didn't
cover it in the video.
It's contained in the textbook.

You'll want to choose the
number of principal components.

Though for principal
components regression,

we can, of course,
use cross validation.

But the way people often
choose the number of components

is by looking at
a plot like this.
This is called a scree plot.

And so people will
look for some break,

some bend in an elbow
of this as a way

to choose the number of
principal components.

Though there's a
lot of discussion

these days about how to
do this in a theoretically
justified way.
But practically speaking.
But this would suggest maybe--
Yeah, something like that.
Yeah.

As it's decaying like
this, there's not really
a big difference between--

there's not a big
change in the rate

as you increase the
number of components.

But I don't have a
theoretical answer for that.
But this is just an eyeballing.

You always add the first
seven principal components
of about 40% of the variance.

So we can see here, that's
about somewhere around 7.

OK, so after having run PCA
on this microarray data,

we're going to take
a look at clustering.

And as in the principal
components analysis,

in a practical sense,
what we're looking for

is when we plot a dendrogram,
say, from a clustering

and cut it somewhere that looks
like a reasonable cut, what

we'd like to see is that
the corresponding clusters

correspond to the
different cancer types.

And this hierarchical
clustering is

very popular in the
genomics community.

Because the data is so big
and wide, hard to look at-- it

gives them one way of
looking at the data.
And it became very popular.
Yes.

So before we cut a
dendrogram, we're

just going to compare
the different linkages.

So we're going to
make three plots.

One for the complete linkage,
one for the average linkage,
and one for the single linkage.
And let's see.

I'll just scroll through
the three of them,

and then I'll come back just
so we can see the difference.
So this is the complete linkage.

And we note there are
a few longish bars.

So a bar like this
is an indication

that this cluster, it was far
away from the next cluster
it was merged with.

If this is really, really
long, then a cluster

that it emanates from
was far from the one
it was finally merged.

So that's an indication
that this is a good place
to cut the dendrogram.

And by the way, because we
know there are some cancer

classes underneath
this, you might

expect to see a bunch
of well-defined clusters
at the top of this picture.
And then not much below.
Yes, that's what we see in here.

Yeah, you can see here
there's a group here.
These are the colon cancers.

And they correspond
to this cluster here.

This group over here
is mostly leukemia.

And that's if I cut
somewhere around there.

So that's what's complete
linkage look like.

The other extreme
is single linkage.

And then I'll talk
about average.
So this is single linkage.

And compared to
complete linkage,
there's really no place--

if we cut anywhere
around here, the results
are going to be very sensitive.
They're going to change a lot.
So there's no natural break.

And this is a common
phenomenon in single linkage.
It's called chaining.

And so what happens is
many of these merges

are just adding on a little
bit to a bigger cluster.

If you look at
these values here,

these are all merging
single points and quite far
along in the clustering process.

Compared to the
complete linkage,

they were about halfway up the
tree when those single points
were merged.

And average linkage, it
unfortunately got a little cut
in the page here.
But it's in between the two.

There's maybe a few
places, a few clusters.

I mean, this range here
might produce some clusters.

But it's not exactly as
clear as complete linkage.
OK.
So now we're going to cut.

So it looks like if we
cut somewhere around here,
there are pretty--

there are some nice
looking clusters
that we can see by eye.

And we'll color them, and then
we'll take a look at the labels

to see if we recovered
things like this colon cancer
group and this leukemia cancer.
OK.

So I'm going to
cut the dendrogram.

We're going to cut
at the level 140.
Let's shrink a little bit.
Let's see.

These purple ones,
it's rather small.

But they seem to be mostly the
leukemia with the exception
of these two.

And I'm not an expert
enough to know.

Those might be a
form of leukemia.

You can make it a bit bigger,
because we can see the--
Yeah, we can see.
That's a good point.
Yeah.

And these red ones, it's
mostly a colon cancer.

Though a few breast
cancers were included.

And again, I'm
not certain enough

to know what that
type of cancer is.
So this isn't perfect.

This cluster over
here, it has a mix.

Maybe a majority breast
cancer, but certainly not pure.

And unfortunately,
we can't expect

to get perfect
separation into classes.

Unless there was a really,
really strong difference.

Also remember, there were 13
different types of cancer here.

So by cutting and
having four groups,

you necessarily are
merging something.
That's a good point.

So what you'd like to see is,
say, for example, in the green,

there's merging of
some cancer classes.

But these cancer classes don't
spread into other clusters.
Yeah.

So there is a subcluster
maybe here of Reno.
But yes.
Yeah, that's a good point.

With only 4, we can
never get all 13.

And also, we only
had 64 subjects.

So to really distinguish
the cancer types,

we probably need more
subjects than that.

Especially because we have
7,000 measurements on each.

So that's an example
of two places

where unsupervised
methods might be used.

The remainder of the
lab also does K-means
clustering on this data.

But as we mentioned before,
hierarchical clustering

is more commonly applied
to this kind of data set.

So we're going to leave
that for you to do offline.
